raw_text:
Williams says he will never quit
 
 Defiant Matt Williams says he will not quit as Scotland coach even if his side slump to a new low with defeat by Italy at Murrayfield.
 
 That would leave the Scots as favourites to win the Wooden Spoon for the second year running. "I have never quit anything in my life, apart from maybe painting the kitchen," he told BBC Sport. "The support we have been given from Murrayfield in my whole time here has been 100%." Williams has yet to experience an RBS Six Nations victory after seven attempts and Scotland have lost 12 of their 14 games under his leadership. But he rejected the comparison made in some media sources with Berti Vogts, recently sacked as Scotland football manager after a poor run of results.
 
 "How can a German football coach and an Australian rugby coach have anything in common?" he asked. "It is a bizarre analogy. It is so absurd that it borders on the humorous." Williams insists that he is revelling in the pressure, despite the possibility of a second Six Nations series without a victory. "That is not beyond the realms of possibility," he admitted. "There's nothing much between the teams, so we could win the next three games or lose them. "But I actually really enjoy seeing how you cope with such pressure as a coach. "It helps the team grow and helps you grow as a coach. "We could have won in Paris but for the last five minutes and now we have two defeats, but we were confident for those two first games and we are confident we can beat Italy too."
llama3.2:1b: Matt Williams will not quit as Scotland's coach despite the team's slump to defeat by Italy at Murrayfield. He has never quit anything in his life apart from painting the kitchen and refuses to comment on a comparison made with Berti Vogts, who was sacked after a poor run of results. Despite Scotland's 12 losses out of 14 games under Williams' leadership, he says he is "revelling in the pressure" and believes they could win three consecutive games if they performed well.
llama3.2:3b: Matt Williams says he will not quit as Scotland coach even after two consecutive losses, despite being at risk of losing the Wooden Spoon. He dismissed comparisons with Berti Vogts, a recently sacked manager, calling it an "absurd analogy".
gemma2:2b: Matt Williams will not resign as Scotland coach despite potential defeat by Italy. He believes his team's performance is comparable to other sports teams and that he enjoys the pressure of coaching underperforming players.  Williams predicts a tough battle in the remaining games but remains optimistic about Scotland's chances of winning.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Matt Williams will never quit his position at Scotland Football Club as he believes it is important to always aim high. He notes that while he has not won the Six Nations in seven attempts under him, Scotland have lost 12 of their last 14 games and they are trailing on their journey to the Wooden Spoon. Williams admits that a German football coach and an Australian rugby coach could potentially be compared due to similar pressures; however, he insists he enjoys working with both teams because it helps develop his skills as a coach. He acknowledges he has not won in Paris but is confident they can win the next three games if they perform well and believes the team's confidence will help them overcome their current difficulties.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Scottish rugby coach Matt Williams vows he will not quit despite Scotland's poor form under his leadership. Despite losing 12 of 14 games, the Scots remain favorites to win the Wooden Spoon for the second year in a row. Williams compares himself to a German football manager and argues that pressure is part of coaching but finds it enjoyable. Despite two defeats, he remains confident they can beat Italy next.
qwen2.5:3b: Matt Williams, Scotland's coach, vows not to quit despite his team's poor performance against Italy, emphasizing support from Murrayfield. He rejects comparisons with recently sacked football manager Berti Vogts and maintains he is enjoying the pressure, viewing it as beneficial for both players and himself. Despite 12 losses out of 14 games under his leadership, Williams remains optimistic about future victories in upcoming Six Nations series.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Williams, his coaching career, and his quotes. Let me read through it carefully.

First, Williams says he will never quit. That's pretty straightforward. He mentions being defiant Matt Williams and the team losing to Italy at Murrayfield. That makes sense because he was on a bit of a slump after that game.

Next, the summary should mention Scotland becoming favourites for the Wooden Spoon with him. He told BBC Sport he hasn't quit since painting his kitchen in college, which shows his determination despite personal challenges.

He's had seven tries to win a Six Nations, but only won three so far. The team has lost 12 of their 14 games under him. He didn't experience an RBS victory yet because the last one was against a weak team. He also said the comparison with Berti Vogts from Australia is bizarre and humorous.

He's trying to enjoy the pressure even though there's still a chance they could win the series without a victory. He mentioned that the teams are similar, so maybe they can still win their next games. Even if they lose two, he says they're confident too because of their first two games.

I think I've got all the key points. Now, I'll put it together into a concise summary with just the text without any extra explanations or formatting.
</think>

Williams will never quit as Scotland coach despite the team slumping to a low-low record following a loss to Italy at Murrayfield. The Scots are expected to become favourites for the Wooden Spoon again. Williams has seven tries to win a Six Nations but hasn't achieved it yet, and they have lost 12 of their 14 games, with only three victories. He maintains a strong support base from Murrayfield, where he's been since college. Despite this, Williams acknowledges a humorous comparison with Berti Vogts from Australia and the risk that his team might not win the series without a victory in the next match.
tinyllama:1.1b: Williams says he will not quit as Scotland's football coach even if his team loses to Italy at Murrayfield. He maintains that the pressure is only beyond his imagination, considering the potential for success. Despite a poor run of results, the coach sees it as an opportunity to grow and develop his coaching abilities.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Williams is determined to win, even if it means facing another losing streak. He remains focused on his duties, despite being out of sync with Berti Vogts' tenure at Scotland. This resilience and determination is echoed by the team, who are experiencing their worst run of results since 2005 under Williams' leadership. Despite the potential implications of a second consecutive losing streak, Williams remains confident in his ability to lead the charge for success on the field.
phi:2.7b: Williams is determined not to quit as Scotland's football manager even after their recent defeat by Italy at Murrayfield. He has received 100% support from the team and believes that they have a chance of winning the wooden spoon for the second year in a row. Despite facing criticism, he sees himself as enjoying the pressure and believes it helps both him and his team grow. Williams admits there is a possibility of losing the next three games but remains confident in their ability to beat Italy too.
orca-mini:3b: Matt Williams says he will not quit as Scotland coach even if his side slump to a new low with defeat by Italy at Murrayfield.
hermes3:3b: Matt Williams refuses to quit as Scotland rugby coach, despite potentially losing to new low with defeat by Italy.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Matt Williams, Scotland's rugby coach, asserts he will never quit despite facing potential defeat that may result in a second consecutive Wooden Spoon win. He dismisses comparisons with Berti Vogts, the recently dismissed Scotland football manager, and expresses his enjoyment of the pressure as it aids team growth and personal development. Despite recent setbacks, Williams remains confident in Scotland's ability to beat Italy and continues to receive strong support from Murrayfield.

Williams embraces the pressure, believing it aids team and personal growth, and remains confident Scotland can still win games despite their poor record.
stablelm2:1.6b: Scotland rugby coach Matt Williams says he will not quit despite potential loss to Italy at Murrayfield, comparing it to a German football coach and an Australian rugby coach. He has yet to win in the Seven Nations but enjoys pressure as a coach, noting there's little difference between teams for upcoming matches. Confidence remains high for upcoming games against Italy and France, with two victories already achieved.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Matt Williams, Scotland's rugby coach, vows to continue his position regardless of a potential defeat by Italy at Murrayfield. This would mark the second consecutive Six Nations title for Italy, with Scotland having never won under his leadership in seven attempts. Despite his team's poor record (12 losses out of 14 games), Williams maintains unwavering resolve and enjoys the pressure, viewing it as a coaching growth opportunity. He dismisses comparisons to former German football manager Berti Vogts, deeming such analogies absurd. Williams remains optimistic about his team's chances against Italy, emphasizing their previous confidence in similar high-pressure matches.
